articles.headline: Tornadoes Kill 25 in Tennessee, Shredding Buildings in Nashville Area
articles.snippet: A powerful storm system cut a path through the middle of Tennessee early Tuesday morning, toppling electrical lines and littering streets with debris.
articles.abstract: A powerful storm system cut a path through the middle of Tennessee early Tuesday morning, toppling electrical lines and littering streets with debris.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOUBLE SPRINGS, Tenn. — Jean Gregory had been fast asleep when her husband yanked her to the floor and flung himself on top of her for six, seven, maybe 10 minutes, as they waited for the tornado that had descended on their small community in Putnam County, Tenn., to finally pass.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas

articles.headline: Iran’s Coronavirus Response: Pride, Paranoia, Secrecy, Chaos
articles.snippet: Iranian leaders once predicted the coronavirus epidemic ravaging China would not affect their country. Now Iran has among the most coronavirus deaths outside China, and Iranian medical workers have been told to keep quiet.
articles.abstract: Iranian leaders once predicted the coronavirus epidemic ravaging China would not affect their country. Now Iran has among the most coronavirus deaths outside China, and Iranian medical workers have been told to keep quiet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly three dozen Iranian government officials and members of parliament are infected and a senior adviser to the supreme leader has died.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Global Health Crisis 1, Economic Policymakers 0
articles.snippet: As leaders of the world’s wealthiest countries pledged to limit the damage from the coronavirus, they appeared to be operating with limited options.
articles.abstract: As leaders of the world’s wealthiest countries pledged to limit the damage from the coronavirus, they appeared to be operating with limited options.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The people who control money had hoped for so much more. The news that the world’s wealthiest countries were convening to orchestrate a response to the deadly coronavirus outbreak had resonated across economies like the sound of whirring helicopters bringing relief to a disaster zone.

articles.headline: The Wall Some Texans Want to Build Against Abortion
articles.snippet: Around the country, a “sanctuary city” movement is growing on the right and the left, as people seek to keep out views they don’t agree with, legal or not.
articles.abstract: Around the country, a “sanctuary city” movement is growing on the right and the left, as people seek to keep out views they don’t agree with, legal or not.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINDALE, Texas — A small group of women at a recent City Council meeting held hands and offered hushed prayers in an otherwise silent room.

articles.headline: What Happens in Vegas if No One Stays in Vegas?
articles.snippet: Companies that rely on people traveling around the globe for business and pleasure are struggling to predict exactly how the coronavirus will ultimately affect them.
articles.abstract: Companies that rely on people traveling around the globe for business and pleasure are struggling to predict exactly how the coronavirus will ultimately affect them.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, thousands of people will travel to Las Vegas for business conferences. The annual South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., is scheduled for this month.

articles.headline: Biden Revives Campaign, Winning Nine States, but Sanders Takes California
articles.snippet: The voting on the biggest day of the Democratic presidential campaign increasingly suggested a two-person race between candidates representing competing wings of the party.
articles.abstract: The voting on the biggest day of the Democratic presidential campaign increasingly suggested a two-person race between candidates representing competing wings of the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential race emerged from Super Tuesday with two clear front-runners as Joseph R. Biden Jr. won Texas, Virginia, North Carolina and at least six other states, largely through support from African-Americans and moderates, while Senator Bernie Sanders harnessed the backing of liberals and young voters to claim the biggest prize of the campaign, California, and several other primaries.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Democrats Decide That Joe Biden, as Risky as He Ever Was, Is the Safest Bet
articles.snippet: The former vice president had the Super Tuesday of his dreams, winning in places he hasn’t even set foot in recently.
articles.abstract: The former vice president had the Super Tuesday of his dreams, winning in places he hasn’t even set foot in recently.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scene, on its face, might not have been surprising a year ago: Joe Biden — appraised among Democrats as a decent man and affable sidekick to the party’s most popular figure — racking up primary victories and having fun talking about it.

articles.headline: Bloomberg Endorses Biden as Sanders Laments Turnout of Younger Voters
articles.snippet: After Mr. Biden’s big wins on Super Tuesday Mr. Bloomberg endorsed him and said that he planned to remain involved in the 2020 presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: After Mr. Biden’s big wins on Super Tuesday Mr. Bloomberg endorsed him and said that he planned to remain involved in the 2020 presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg dropped out of the presidential race and backed Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday, throwing the financial might of the Democratic Party’s biggest benefactor behind the former vice president’s campaign as Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont vowed to wage a long battle for the nomination.

articles.headline: ‘When Can We Go to School?’ Nearly 300 Million Children Are Missing Class
articles.snippet: The global scale and speed of the educational disruption from the coronavirus epidemic is “unparalleled,” the United Nations said.
articles.abstract: The global scale and speed of the educational disruption from the coronavirus epidemic is “unparalleled,” the United Nations said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The coronavirus epidemic has reached deeper into daily life across the world, with a sweeping shutdown of all schools in Italy, a suspension of classes in India’s capital and warnings of school closures in the United States, intensifying the educational upheaval of nearly 300 million students globally.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang and Makiko Inoue
